title: 110_hr5523
content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" is a new law that amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a license fee for internet gambling operators and requires them to report licensee information. The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" introduces a license fee for internet gambling operators. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008 requires licensed internet gambling operators to pay a 2 percent license fee on all funds deposited into accounts used for betting or wagering. Winnings deposits are excluded from this fee. The Internet gambling license fees paid by operators are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue. The fee is the exclusive obligation of the operator and cannot be deducted from bet amounts. The term 'Director' refers to the meaning in section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. Administrative provisions are determined by the Secretary. The Internet gambling license fee is treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. Information returns related to special provisions are amended to include this fee. "SEC. 6039J. RETURNS OF INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide required information to the Secretary as prescribed by regulations, and maintain appropriate records. The information includes the operator's name, address, and other details determined by the Secretary. The Internet gambling operator must provide the IRS with the name, address, tax information number, and financial details of each person who placed wagers during the year, including gross winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, account balances, and transaction amounts. The IRS requires every person to furnish a written statement to individuals whose information is included in their tax return, including contact details and required information by January 31 of the following year. The IRS mandates that individuals must provide a written statement to those included in their tax return by January 31 of the following year. Additionally, clerical amendments are made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36. The IRS requires individuals to provide a written statement to those on their tax return by January 31 of the following year. Amendments are made to the table of sections for internet gambling operators, with the effective date for wagers made after December 31, 2008. Additionally, withholding from certain gambling winnings is addressed in Section 3. Amendments are made to the withholding of net internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year. Winnings not exempt from withholding are specified, and definitions are updated in the tax code. The tax code is amended to include definitions for net internet gambling winnings and proceeds of net internet gambling winnings, specifying amounts subject to withholding over $5,000 in a calendar year. The tax code is amended to define net internet gambling winnings for withholding purposes. The tax code is amended to treat net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments, with Internet gambling operators as payors and wager placers as payees. Effective after December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. The text discusses amendments to tax laws for nonresident alien individuals, including a 30 percent tax on income not connected with US business and an exemption for certain gambling winnings, including internet gambling income. Amendments to tax laws for nonresident alien individuals include withholding tax on net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year, effective for wagers placed after December 31, 2008. Tax on wagers is addressed in Section 5. Persons placing wagers with unlicensed individuals are liable for tax under this subchapter. Wagers placed within the United States by US citizens or residents are subject to tax. These amendments are effective immediately. The amendments made by this section apply to wagers made after December 31, 2008.
